awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Xue Liu  is " Spaces of triangulations and subdivisions". The host institution for the fellowship is the Max Planck Institute, Germany, and the sponsoring scientist is Karim Adiprasito.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Xue Liu conducted research in the area of combinatorics under the NSF Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship. The research took place at the Max Planck Institute for Mathemtics in the Sciences in Leipzig, Germany, and the KTH Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm, Sweden.

The subject of the research was triangulations and subdivisions of geometric spaces. Triangulations and subdivisions are ways to break down a space into smaller, more manageable pieces. For example, 3D graphics are created by breaking a 2D space into triangles, i.e. a triangulation. There are many unanswered theoretical questions about these objects that Liu sought to answer with his research.

In joint work with Karim Adiprasito and Michael Temkin, Liu solved a long-standing question in algebraic geometry known as the "semistable reduction" conjecture. First proposed by Abramovich and Karu, this conjecture concerns objects called "varities", which are solutions sets to systems of polynomial equations. The semistable reduction conjecture attempts to replace badly-behaved, or "singular" families of varieties with nicer, or "smoother" ones. The aforementioned researchers showed that this is always possible by proving the existence of nice triangulations called "unimodular triangulations". The result has far-reaching consequences in the study of algebraic geometry.

In joint work with Rob Edman, Pakawut Jiradilok, and Thomas McConville, Liu studied the space of monotone paths on zonotopes. Monotone paths are closely realted to an algorith known as the "simplex method" which attemps to optimize a linear function over a polyhedral parameter space. The space of all monotone paths is a well-studied and interesting object. The authors classified all zonotopes, a particular type of polyhedron, which admit nice monotone path spaces. Their research may have applications in the study of polytope diameters and the simplex method.

In joint work with Karim Adiprasito, Liu studied geomtric spaces called cubical manifolds. Cubical manifolds are spaces formed by glueing cubes together. They are of great inteest in geometry and topology. Cubical manifolds can be transformed through a process called "flipping". However, not all cubical manifolds can be transformed to one another through this process. The authors characterized which manifolds can be transformed to each other through this process. Their result establishes a surprising connection between the combinatorics of cubes and a notion in topology called "cobordism".

During the research period, Liu helped mentor graduate students, serving as the main advisor for one students' masters thesis. He also co-organized a conference at the Max Planck Institute which brought together students and senior researchers to establish career connections and initiate research collaborations.
